protocol_name: MG_HW2: Downloading SRA data using the SRA toolkit
protocol_name_html: MG_HW2: Downloading SRA data using the SRA toolkit
description: The Sequence Read Archive (SRA) is a database for biological sequence data and is maintained by the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI). Sequence files can be obtained by using the SRA Toolkit. This protocol provides the steps necessary to use the SRA toolkit to get sequence data in fastq format.
before_start: Login to the UA hpc. This protocol will begin in your home directory.

components.data:
Make sure you have /rsgrps/bh_class/bin in your path:

 

If you don't, you will get an error message like this:

2016-09-12T17:15:17 prefetch.2.4.4 int: path not found while resolving tree - cannot get cache location for SRR1647046
components.name: Description

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 1 of MG_HW2: Downloading SRA data using the SRA toolkit
source_data.protocol_name: MG_HW2: Downloading SRA data using the SRA toolkit
source_data.protocol_name_html: MG_HW2: Downloading SRA data using the SRA toolkit
source_data.annotation: This step allows you to execute the executable files found in /rsgrps/bh_class/bin. Executable files appear green on the HPC.
source_data.thread_text: This step allows you to execute the executable files found in /rsgrps/bh_class/bin. Executable files appear green on the HPC.
source_data.body: This step allows you to execute the executable files found in /rsgrps/bh_class/bin. Executable files appear green on the HPC.

source_data.name:
$ cd
$ nano .bashrc

export PATH=/rsgrps/bh_class/bin:$PATH

$ source .bashrc
source_data.description: export PATH=/rsgrps/bh_class/bin:$PATH is copied into .bashrc. Then save and quit nano to source it.

components.data: Utilize the "prefetch" command from the SRA toolkit to get your SRA file.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Utilize the "prefetch" command from the SRA toolkit to get your SRA file.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 2 of MG_HW2: Downloading SRA data using the SRA toolkit

source_data.annotation: Your SRR numbers are found in the google drive sheet shared with the class under column 'M' . There should be a total of 8 files you need to download. See next step on how to download multiple files at once.
source_data.thread_text: Your SRR numbers are found in the google drive sheet shared with the class under column 'M' . There should be a total of 8 files you need to download. See next step on how to download multiple files at once.
source_data.body: Your SRR numbers are found in the google drive sheet shared with the class under column 'M' . There should be a total of 8 files you need to download. See next step on how to download multiple files at once.

source_data.name: $ prefetch SRR1647145
source_data.description: NOTE: make sure to use your SRR number

components.data: You can pass 'prefetch' multiple arguments to download all data files at once:
components.name: Description

source_data.description: You can pass 'prefetch' multiple arguments to download all data files at once:

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 3 of MG_HW2: Downloading SRA data using the SRA toolkit
source_data.protocol_name: MG_HW2: Downloading SRA data using the SRA toolkit
source_data.protocol_name_html: MG_HW2: Downloading SRA data using the SRA toolkit
source_data.annotation:
Rather than copying and pasting each file name, you can use Unix to help you!

 

# make a file with the list of SRR files copied from the excel spread sheet

% nano list

 

# use the translate command to convert new lines to spaces.  Note the space in the second set of quotes.

 

% tr '\n' ' ' < list

 

# then copy the line with the file names separated by space into the prefetch command, as below.
source_data.thread_text:
Rather than copying and pasting each file name, you can use Unix to help you!

 

# make a file with the list of SRR files copied from the excel spread sheet

% nano list

 

# use the translate command to convert new lines to spaces.  Note the space in the second set of quotes.

# then copy the line with the file names separated by space into the prefetch command, as below.
source_data.body:
Rather than copying and pasting each file name, you can use Unix to help you!

 

# make a file with the list of SRR files copied from the excel spread sheet

% nano list

 

# use the translate command to convert new lines to spaces.  Note the space in the second set of quotes.

 

% tr '\n' ' ' < list

 

# then copy the line with the file names separated by space into the prefetch command, as below.

source_data.name: $ prefetch SRR1647238 SRR1647240 SRR1647144 SRR1647260 SRR1647239 SRR1647236 SRR1647237
source_data.description: NOTE: make sure you use your SRR numbers .

components.data:
The .sra files will be stored in ~/ncbi/public/sra

 

Move into that directory, then make sure all 8 files are present:
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
The .sra files will be stored in ~/ncbi/public/sra

 

Move into that directory, then make sure all 8 files are present:

source_data.result: SRR390728.sra  SRR1647238.sra  SRR1647240.sra SRR1647144.sra  SRR1647260.sra SRR1647239.sra SRR1647236.sra SRR1647237.sra

components.data: Convert the .sra file into fastq format using the fastq-dump command from the SRA toolkit. All files can be converted in one command by passing fastq-dump all files with the .sra extension.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Convert the .sra file into fastq format using the fastq-dump command from the SRA toolkit. All files can be converted in one command by passing fastq-dump all files with the .sra extension.

source_data.name: $ fastq-dump *.sra
source_data.description:
*.sra defines all files with a .sra extension 

NOTE: make sure you are in ~/ncbi/public/sra when you execute this command.

components.data: Now check to see you have 8 .fastq files, 1 for each .sra file. Make a /rsgrps/bh_class/<user>/fastq directory.  Where you will replace <user> with your github id.  Then move all of the all fastq files there for later use.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Now check to see you have 8 .fastq files, 1 for each .sra file. Make a /rsgrps/bh_class/<user>/fastq directory.  Where you will replace <user> with your github id.  Then move all of the all fastq files there for later use.

source_data.name:
ls
mkdir -p /rsgrps/bh_class/bhurwitz/fastq
mv *fastq !$
cd !$
ls
source_data.description:
use mkdir -p to create all directories listed.  In this case, we are creating bhurwitz (my user id) and the fastq directories.
Note that you should use your github id here, so we can track your user id easily, and so it is consistent with your homework.
Note that I am using !$ to use the argument from the last command line.

components.data: SRR390728.fastq  SRR1647238.fastq  SRR1647240.fastq SRR1647144.fastq  SRR1647260.fastq SRR1647239.fastq SRR1647236.fastq SRR1647237.fastq
components.name: Expected result

source_data.result: SRR390728.fastq  SRR1647238.fastq  SRR1647240.fastq SRR1647144.fastq  SRR1647260.fastq SRR1647239.fastq SRR1647236.fastq SRR1647237.fastq

source_data.name: $ seqmagick info ./*.fastq --input-format fastq > readcounts.txt
source_data.description: seqmagick info will generate sequence statistics for all fastq files found in the current directory and redirect the output into a file.

components.data:
Input the seqmagick 'num_seqs' results for each sample into a summary table entitled 'Table 1'. The format should be:

 

Table 1:

 

sample name num_seqs
SRR1647144 2533849
SRR1647145 3649566
SRR1647236 3051288
SRR1647237 1856522
SRR1647238 492203
SRR1647239 11191553
SRR1647240 1527542
SRR1647260 39872

components.data:
Add metadata for each sample to your summary table. This information can be found in columns K (Occlusion_s), Q (Age_s), R (Sex_s), S (Site_Categories), T (Site_Symbol_s), V (TimePoint_s), and X (Visit_Date_s) from the google doc. The resulting table should look like this:

 

Table 1:

 

sample name num_seqs occlusion_s age_s sex_s site_categories site_symbol_s timepoint_s visit_date_s
SRR1647144 2533849 Intermittently_Occluded 24 Female Rarely_Intermittently_Moist Ac 2 8/19/13
SRR1647145 3649566 Occluded 24 Female Moist Ax 2 8/19/13
SRR1647236 3051288 Exposed 24 Female Sebaceous Fh 2 8/19/13
SRR1647237 1856522 Exposed 24 Female Rarely_Intermittently_Moist Pa 2 8/19/13
SRR1647238 492203 Occluded 24 Female Sebaceous Ra 2 8/19/13
SRR1647239 11191553 Exposed 24 Female Sebaceous Sc 2 8/19/13
SRR1647240 1527542 Occluded 24 Female Moist Tw 2 8/19/13
SRR1647260 39872

 Occluded 24 Female Moist Um 2 8/19/13
